results.title: Television: behind the scenes
results.brief_description: The number of television licenses in the Federal Republic of Germany has passed the ten million mark. This film takes a look behind the scenes and shows, apart from the technical details, interesting facts about the production of television programs.

results.title: Television system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Television”
Explains the principles of television broadcasting, from the camera tube at the studio to the receiver. Shows how the image is brokenm down into picture elements, clarifies the procedure of interfacing; explains the function of each component of the video signal, shows how the scanning raster is produced and the image reproduced in shades of black and white on the screen.

results.title: Television receivers
results.creator_credit: Loucks and Norling Studios and McGraw-Hill Text-Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Television”
Diagrams and live action are used to identify the sections of the receiver circuit and to summarise the functions of the receiver. Explains the specific functions of each section in a typical intercarrier sound receiver circuit, from the antenna and transmission line to the picture tube.

results.title: Television picture tube
results.brief_description: Shows how the electron-beam of the cathode ray tube is made to deflect both horizontally and vertically so that it becomes a scanning device over the face of the television screen. Also shows modulation of intensity of the beam.

results.title: Television and the world
results.brief_description: Filmed to commemorate BBC-TV’s 25th anniversary, this documentary takes us on journey through 10 countries, showing the impact of television on people from different cultures. Beginning in Italy where production is determined by the government and a literacy program screens at dusk. TV arrived in Egypt in 1960 and has been aimed predominantly at the wealthy. In Thailand, TV is heavily regulated by the State. Japan are amongst the world’s leaders in television engineering, their programs include both eastern and western content. In the USA viewers responding to a survey have indicated that TV is too violent and too commercial. In Brazil, 50% of television content is taken up by commercials, which can be interrupted by wealthy politicians for public announcements. Russian television targets propaganda to housewives, but protects its children from violence focusing on educational and entertaining programs. Polish television is run by the communist party and focuses on national issues. Nigerian television devotes morning programs to education and evening sessions to entertainment. A small experimental unit operates in India, while South Africa’s policy is no television at all. What emerges chiefly is the dependence of all countries, outside the East European bloc, on ‘trashy’ American films that inaccurately portrayed life. Photographed by Kenneth Westbury; edited by Harry Hastings; commentary by Michael Flanders.

results.brief_description: An informative training video for businesses, government and private organisations - indeed for anyone whose services are promoted through telephone contact with the public.

results.title: Telephone technique [B&W]
results.brief_description: Part of a series on sales training, this episode deals with telephone training for retail sales clerks. It emphasizes good telephone manners, wide knowledge of stock, importance of correct customer name and address, and the necessity for an intelligent descriptive vocabulary when speaking of merchandise over the telephone.

results.title: Telephone presentation and time management
results.brief_description: As a medium for information exchange, the telephone is constantly evolving, and so too are the techniques we use to make this powerful tool work for us in the business community. It’s important that we master these techniques. This video aims to improve your presentation and time management with the telephone in terms of your voice (variations in tone, pitch and volume), spelling out difficult names or numbers, good listening, mood, techniques for putting callers at ease and etiquette for receiving business calls using “hold” options and note taking.

results.title: Telephone exchange
results.creator_credit: David Cons, Denis Ward and Technical and Scientific Films
results.brief_description: Shows by diagrams, models and live action the basic working of an automatic telephone exchange. Comparisons with a manual exchange. Demonstrates working of a uniselector, dialling a number and the subsequent connection. Shows correct method of dialling.

results.title: Telephone etiquette
results.brief_description: Telephone etiquette is vitally important in ensuring effective information flow. This short instructional video covers the main points in telephone etiquette, including identification of the caller/receiver of the call; politeness; using answering machines; tact and discretion and how to deal with difficult customers.
